channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: These doctors want to break the cycle of shame and blame in medicine
item.description: Shaming is common in medical school and unfortunately, sometimes in the doctor's office. Some doctors are trying to teach medical students awareness of the problem so they don't perpetuate the cycle.
item.content:encoded:
Shaming is common in medical school and unfortunately, sometimes in the doctor's office. Some doctors are trying to teach medical students awareness of the problem so they don't perpetuate the cycle.

(Image credit: fpphotobank/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Huff

item.title: Senate Republicans deal Trump a rare rebuke on trade with vote against Brazil tariffs
item.description: Five Republicans joined with Democrats on a vote to end the national emergency that President Trump has declared as the basis for sweeping tariffs on Brazil.
item.content:encoded:
Five Republicans joined with Democrats on a vote to end the national emergency that President Trump has declared as the basis for sweeping tariffs on Brazil.

(Image credit: Mario Tama)
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: A matchmaking site helps farmers find buyers for their land
item.description: Websites fashioned like online marketplaces match aspiring farmers with land owners who want to pass their property to someone who will be a good steward of their work. It's part of a growing trend.
item.content:encoded: Websites fashioned like online marketplaces match aspiring farmers with land owners who want to pass their property to someone who will be a good steward of their work. It's part of a growing trend.
item.dc:creator: Sophia Saliby

item.title: The Sudanese army's last stronghold in Darfur has fallen to paramilitary forces
item.description: Sudan's army has retreated from the key Darfur city of El Fasher after an 18-month siege amid reports of mass civilian deaths.
item.content:encoded: Sudan's army has retreated from the key Darfur city of El Fasher after an 18-month siege amid reports of mass civilian deaths.
item.dc:creator: Kate Bartlett

item.title: Want to opt out of AI? State labeling laws might help
item.description: Some states are passing new laws requiring artificial intelligence to be clearly labeled, especially in regulated industries or on high-stakes documents such as police reports. The labels are crucial for people who'd rather not use AI at all.
item.content:encoded:
Some states are passing new laws requiring artificial intelligence to be clearly labeled, especially in regulated industries or on high-stakes documents such as police reports. The labels are crucial for people who'd rather not use AI at all.

(Image credit: Smith Collection)
item.dc:creator: Martin Kaste

item.title: How to decide whether to step back from a difficult relationship — or stick it out
item.description: When a loved one is behaving in a way that bothers you, should you lean into the relationship or take a break? If you're having trouble deciding, therapist KC Davis offers guiding questions.
item.content:encoded: When a loved one is behaving in a way that bothers you, should you lean into the relationship or take a break? If you're having trouble deciding, therapist KC Davis offers guiding questions.
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: How Israel is winning the wars and losing the peace
item.description: Israel has strengthened its security with a series of sweeping military victories in the past two years. It has also become far more isolated internationally, with no clear path ahead.
item.content:encoded:
Israel has strengthened its security with a series of sweeping military victories in the past two years. It has also become far more isolated internationally, with no clear path ahead.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Are you worried about your SNAP benefits? NPR wants to hear your story
item.description: As the federal government shutdown drags on, tens of millions of people are at risk of losing food and nutrition aid as a result. The NPR Network wants to hear from you about the potential loss or delay of these food benefits.
item.content:encoded:
As the federal government shutdown drags on, tens of millions of people are at risk of losing food and nutrition aid as a result. The NPR Network wants to hear from you about the potential loss or delay of these food benefits.

(Image credit: Allison Dinner)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: SNAP runs out of money Nov. 1. States are now figuring out how to feed millions of people
item.description: As November looms, states are trying to sort what options they can offer beneficiaries to fill the gap in food assistance. Reporters from the NPR Network are covering the impact of this potential lapse in states across the country.
item.content:encoded:
As November looms, states are trying to sort what options they can offer beneficiaries to fill the gap in food assistance. Reporters from the NPR Network are covering the impact of this potential lapse in states across the country.

(Image credit: Tyrone Turner)
item.dc:creator: The NPR Network

item.title: Category 5 Hurricane Melissa brings flooding and catastrophic winds to Jamaica
item.description: The Caribbean storm — among the most powerful in history, with 185 mph winds — is expected to bring flash-flooding and landslides as it slowly moves across the island and heads north toward Cuba.
item.content:encoded:
The Caribbean storm — among the most powerful in history, with 185 mph winds — is expected to bring flash-flooding and landslides as it slowly moves across the island and heads north toward Cuba.

(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
